title: Riot there's too much cancer in-game to allow double bans anymore, champs should be banned once only
body:
And the solution to allow for this is beyond simple: Just make enemy bans visible to the other side and prevent duplicates from happening like how two people on one side can't double-ban the same character currently.

And to all of you out there that are no doubt going to come rushing in with the BS thoughtless argument: "Oh but you'll ban out entire champ pools!" I respond with: "Why are the perma-banned cancer-champs the only thing you can play?"

This Would Work.

Elaborate on the proposal more, when exactly are the bans being shown. On lock, on hover? There are some unintended consequences specific to each version that while allowing more champions to be banned could have significant negative effects overall, but need to know which one so I can critique it properly.
There are 140+ champions. Banning 10 of those is roughly 7% of the characters you can play. 93% of 140 champions are available.  Exactly what problems would occur?

I'll highlight the second worst case, that of de-dupe on hover, to make the point. Little disappointed that op did not go into more detail though.

If you de-dupe on hover, the optimal choice is to hover-ban one of the champions that you yourself wish to play, then swap at the last moment to something else, preventing them from being banned. You have the flexibility to not play that champion if it looks like the enemy team is going to counter based off of information given, but if they don't you've effectively nullified the enemy teams banning potential.

There is a saying in Magic:  The Gathering:

"Free information is free."

In that game, it means that pro players never give away any free information about their hand, board state, or intended actions, because this free information helps their opponent choose better and more efficient responses against them.

Translated over to League, under your proposed system,  the team that bans first is giving free information to their opponents.  Said opponents can then use that information to make better choices and counterbans and counterpicks.  

In other words, if your opponent bans first, then you get to see your opponent's bans before you do, and these bans may reveal things to you about their potential positions and playstyles that you can use to make more efficient choices.  As most people playing this game for any length of time have found out, very skillful players sometimes only need a slight edge in efficiency to begin a snowball.

TL:DR - Whoever bans last gains an advantage under this proposed system.

---------------

In high-level play this naturally must lead to a lot of people delaying their bans as long as possible to avoid giving away this advantage.  I think we'd probably see a lot more accidentally dodged matches at higher ELO as people try to time their bans to the end of the timer and miss, and lower-skill players being somewhat taken advantage of in lower ELO due to not understanding what free information they give away, if this system were implemented.

By expanding the ban pool to 10 individual champs, you encourage banning more fringe champs as well as the "pervasive and awful to deal with champs."

One small flaw with that plan; if both teams can only ban a champ once (so no one unintentionally double bans a champ), then the opposing team would gain intelligence sooner than intended (what type of champs the enemy does not want to face).
